dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the full light all the details of the sprawled body, limp neck and disordered hair of the victim can be seen as well as the cheaply furnished room with tis sorry appointments, bed bureau, chair, desk and a rocker by the window with incongruous velour curtain.  Over the bed in a cracked and gilded frame, Pail and Virginia run ceaselessly from the storm.  From the other wall Rose Benhaur's doer-eyed horses, water dripping from their muzzles gaze down on the murdered woman from a frame of false metal bits, stirrup irons and spurs.  The CAMERAS momentarily contemplation of all this is interrupted by two voices, the first questioning, the second affirmative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homicide?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homicide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REVERSE ANGLE to show the doorway blocked with blue serge, blue uniforms, brass buttons and Homberg hats.  John Mitchell, a patrolman with that surprising youngness of a rookie just out of polic school, backs against the door jamb to let two older plain-clothes men go through.  They go toward the body.  A Cameraman steers the waivering legs of his tripod to solid footing in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Mitchell; complaining) I can't take a picture through you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitchell steps back into the hallway.  The cameraman grunts his gratitude.  Behind him, as Mitchell steps out of frame, can be seen the white-coated figures of an ambulance doctor and an orderly.  The orderly holds a rolled stretcher and cuts diagonally across the scene.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSE
dialogues.text: As Mitchell steps back a naked electric bulb throws harsh light on the faces crowded in the narrow space between the stair rail and rose patterned wallpaper.  The cruel light cannot destroy the soft lines and pleasant contours of Sally Notcheck's young face, but only highlights the wide eyes and flushed cheeks, the animation, the terror and excitement that the fact of murder has communicated to her and which she is so busily passing on to the middle-aged Lieutenant Detective who stands courteously, hat in hand, before her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turned back -- as if he were looking for something -- then he ran right past me -- right past me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She makes a gesture with her hand to indicate the swiftness of the close passage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looked at me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you looked at him?  A good look?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sally nods excitedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell us about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was young -- younger than Mrs. MacIlWain -- blonde -- sort of brownish blonde.  He had a pale face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tall? Short?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tall -- I guess -- thin -- but not very thin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see him before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sally shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I could pick him out if I saw him again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lieutenant Detective nods, almost smiles; he has head this before.  He looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's the patrolman here on this beat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitchell steps forward, saluting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrolman Mitchell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever see a fellow like that around here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that I can remember, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Mainwairing is the proprietor of the rooming house, middle-aged, but dimpled, with kewpie doll makeup around the eyes, dyed hair relentlessly coifed and curled.  She moves her heavy body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never seen him.  But Wednesdays and Fridays was his night to come up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wednesdays and Fridays?  What kind of place is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's ok, sir -- perfectly respectable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house has always had a good reputation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let it ride.  I was making a joke -- you know -- a joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. MacIlwain was perfectly respectable too.  This fellow was her steady boy-friend.  That's why they had regular date nights -- Wednesdays and Fridays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never saw him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't bother the tenants.  I stay downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lieutenant turns to Sally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd he wear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brown suit, I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitantly) No, I think he had it in his hand.  A tan hat.  That's right, it was in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A terrible -- terrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lieutenant looks at her, the ponderously turns and goes toward the door of Mrs. MacIlwain's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cameraman, his camera focused on the body takes a picture with a flash bulb; living and dying in an instant of blinding brightness.  The Lieutenant enters, strides to the center of the room, planting his ponderous feet within a few inches of the dead woman's outstretched legs.  He looks around.  One detective stands at the desk rifling through the pages of a book, shaking it so that nay hidden papers or money would fall out.  Another is rummaging through the clothes closet.  A third has spread white powder over the foot board of the bed and is examining it carefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no answer.  He snorts and throws out the word again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just smudges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fellow once told me most murder victims have diaries.  I can't find nothin' but bills and some letters about alimony from a lawyer four years back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moths here -- in her winter coat.  There's some stuff my wife uses --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah -- the moths killed her.  What'd you find beside moths?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANOTHER ANGLE OF THE ROOM as the Detective at the closet reaches down and picks up a pair of men's galoshes and throws them out into the middle of the room. CLOSET FULL SHOT - as the Lieutenant takes a step toward the galoshes, picks one up, glances at it and lets it fall from his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll take these along. (To the doctor and orderly waiting in the doorway) You guys take this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to the body.  He then starts from the room and behind him one of the detectives picks up the overshoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Lieutenant emerges and starts toward the stairs, Mitchell moves forward to speak to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you get any clues?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About as much as we usually get -- nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Eagerly) We've go a good description of him.  I'll keep my eyes open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah -- you do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT - of the proof room taking in the long horizontal lines of the tables and the overhead lights that march down the room one after the other, each with its pendant pool of light and under each light proof readers hunched quietly, their pens nibbling at error. A shirt-sleeved boy with a square paper hat on his head goes past the CAMERA, proof sheets writhing in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: STREET
dialogues.text: From the middle of the street the parked ambulance, a patrol car and police sedan can be seen parked at the curb.  The patrol car, its front wheels turned toward the house, its lights on to illuminate the steps of the brown-stone, cut a sharp, white plane across the sidewalk.  A small crowd has gathered to gawk and three uniformed policeman stand idly by.  It is shirt-sleeve weather, late August, and the faces of the people are shiny wet with the spent heat of the day. The Lieutenant of Detectives, followed by his men, comes down the steps.  There is a stir in the crowd, a craning of necks.  He walks swiftly across the sidewalk.  A police chauffeur holds open the door.  The Lieutenant steps in and takes his seat.  One of the detectives is about to follow him when an untidy little man, his coat pockets crowded with warn copies of Harper's Magazine, New Departures an Story, pushes through the crowd and past the detective to poke his head into the doorway of the sedan. REVERSE ANGLE - to show this man, Henry Hamlin, a reporter, as he pokes his head into the doorway of the police sedan to face the Lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, Lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lieutenant grunts in greeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi-yah, Hamlin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you ask the question, sir, I can only reply that I am unfortunate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was I who had to leave on this burning night the delights of cold bear, hot pastrami to follow you and your investigation of great crimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lose the cut, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rest sit comfortably while I pursue their business with my own.  What's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman got killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In mispronounced French) En crime passion --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was this unfortunate that shucked these mortal coils?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll tell you upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He makes a preemptory gesture to the detective who pushes Hamlin to one side and gets into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (As he withdraws) Farewell, brave minion of the law. (He pauses) Of averages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other detectives crowd into the car, the door closes and the car starts off with a blast from the siren.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT - up the avenue showing the swift and orderly stream of traffic, the headlights glowing two-by=two like the eyes of feral creatures some dread clan had regimented into these swift and seried ranks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lieutenant and his men sit quietly, relaxed, swaying to the accustomed motion of the vehicle.  One of the detectives is seated on the jump seat and holds the galoshes in his hand.  Suddenly the silence is broken by the Lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much to go on -- a pair of men's galoshes left in the apartment last winter -- an ex-husband -- the last four years ex -- a girl who saw the murderer -- that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy was there every Wednesday and Friday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check the overshoes.  Find out who made 'em, where they were sold -- who bought 'em -- you do that Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tidy little job in this weather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll check the ex-husband -- don't expect much.  Not after four years -- and the neighborhood -- she must have bought papers, groceries, cigarettes -- might have talked to the people.  Woman like that usually talk to somebody -- all she's got to talk about is boy friends -- or boy friend. (he heaves a long sigh) Where're we goin' now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Without turning his head replies to the question) Man don on sidewalk after fight.  Thought to be dying -- fifty eight street -- near the Circle -- ambulance is there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chauffeur steps on the siren.  As it SOUNDS:

DOLLY SHOT - The CAMERA follows the boy.  At each desk he deposits a few proof sheets and the darker, wider pages of copy.  Finally, at one desk, he lays down a proof sheet and a copy sheet and then goes on.  The CAMERA remains fixed on the slightly built, thin-faced greying man who sits there.  He lifts his head as he reaches forward to pull the proof sheet toward him. INSERT: As the proof readers hands pull the proof sheets closer a pen poises over the lines and begins to follow them closely making small space and indentation corrections on the following copy. "At the street where she had lived for the past two years, Mrs. Dorothy Macillwain, a divorcee, met death last night at the hands of an unknown assailant.  The murderer, a constant visitor --" At the name "Macillwain" the pen pauses for a long pause, then very slowly lowers and makes the correction to "MacIlwain." CLOSE SHOT - The proof reader's face, motionless and impassive, the pen resting on the corrected name.  Very slowly the CAMERA moves further left to shoot past his profile to take in the neat name on the desk.  It reads: Herbert S. MacIlwain.

dialogues.speaker: EX. MRS. MAINWAITING'S ROOMING HOUSE
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT - Mrs. Mainwairing on the doorstep.  This is a rear view of Mrs. Mainwairing's becurled poll, fatted shoulders, pendant flanks and pachydermian haunches.  She is busily screwing some object to the wall of her house.  Over this back view of Mrs. Mainwairing can be heard two of the distinctive street cries of New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old clothes, old clothes, who got, who got, who got any old clothes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bones, bottles, brass, j-u-u-u-nk!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man walking along the street pauses and looks up at Mrs. Mainwairing.  After a second or two she is conscious of his gaze and turns.  As she turns she reveals that what she has been screwing to the wall is an enameled sign which reads, "Room To Let." REVERSE VIEW from Mrs. Mainwairing's angle to show that the man is MacIlwain.  He tips his hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder if I might see that room, madame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. FULL SHOT - Mrs. Mainwairing from his angle as he starts up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes indeedy!  It's a lovely single -- just right for a gentleman -- sun in the morning -- nice soft bed -- lovely soft bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MacIlwain has climbed to her level and she turns to lead the way into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL SHOT of the lower hall as Mrs. Mainwairing enters, followed by MacIlwain.  She starts up the stairs, puffing and panting at each step.  She is short of breath but not of words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's such a nice room -- I've always thought of it as gentleman's room -- near the bath -- nice rocker by the window and my husband's favorite painting --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're married?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh dear no.  So many of us girls are divorced these days.  Have to share the boys you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pass out of view on their way up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't often have vacancies in this house.  It's just pure accident that I have one now -- just pure accident.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSE
dialogues.text: As Mrs. Mainwairing and Mr. MacIlwain come up they start down the hall toward the room formerly occupied by Mrs. MacIlwain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Stepping aside to let him look through the open doorway) This is the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE FULL SHOT - of MacIlwain in the door as he stands looking in.  Over this shot can be heard a peculiar rhythmic noise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Mr. MacIlwain's ANGLE at the door.  The bed has been stripped, the windows opened and the curtains are blowing.  A scrub woman kneels at the bedside, a bucket beside her, busily shampooing the rug where Mrs. MacIlwain's body had lain. Mr. MacIlwain comes in past the CAMERA and stands looking down at the scub woman. MED. CLOSE SHOT - MacIlwain as he transfers his attention from the rug. PAN SHOT - from MacIlwain's ANGLE to take in the freshly emptied closet, the open drawers of the bureau and finally the curtains blowing at the open windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always like to get a room cleaned for the new tenant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FULL TWO SHOT - as she comes into scene MacIlwain turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lady who had the room was just crazy about it. (She pauses) She had to leave -- such a nice woman too -- such a nice woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Such a nice woman?  My name is MacIlwain.  I was her husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and starts for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the door he pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanted top see the room -- you understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Very flustered) Oh yes -- yes.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSE
dialogues.text: MacIlwain comes out of his dead wife's room, goes down the hall and starts down the stairs.  From below him comes a man's merry whistling of "The Harp That Once Through Terra's Halls" and the thud of thick-soled shoes on the worn carpet of the stair.

dialogues.speaker: MORNING
dialogues.text: MacIlwain, on hs way down, passes Patrolman Mitchell on his way out.  The patrolman crowds himself against the wall to let the other man pass, breaks off his whistle and watches MacIlwain as he goes down the stairs, transverse the lower hall and leaves the building. When the front door is closed behind MacIlwain, Mitchell resumes his climb up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: HOUSE
dialogues.text: AN ANGLE that shows Mrs. Mainwairing leaning over the railing looking down.  Mitchell comes on a level with her and pushes his cap back on the back of his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning, Mrs. Mainwairing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Without replying to his greeting) You know who that was?  That was Mrs. MacIlwain's husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Her husband.  He said so.  He wanted to see the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He did, eh?  Did he tell you anything about himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a thing.  Just that he was her husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wanted to see where she died, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess so.  Something like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he tell you his first name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Mainwairing shakes her head.  Mitchell sighs and pushes his cap further back on his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I guess I could locate him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for?  He didn't do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He might give me a lead on who did. (He pauses) You know -- I'd like to get the guy who did it.  Yeah, I would.  You know what it would mean to me -- promotion maybe -- plain-clothes duty, maybe -- thirty bucks more a month.  The wife and I could use that.  There's a little apartment my brother-in-law could get us in Flushing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flushing's nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice for the kids -- a place to play -- decent people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a good place to bring up kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah -- if I could get the guy.  You could help me Mrs. Mainwairing.  Let me know if anybody comes around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They always return to the scene of the crime, don't they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know about that -- but if anybody comes around, you'll let me know, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes indeedy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns and starts down the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if anybody asks you about a good room, you tell 'em about my room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: MORNING
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT of this residential street with its walkup apartment houses all a little run down, stained with time and weather.  There are only a few passersby.  One of them is MacIlwain.  He walks slowly on the south side of the street looking at the second story windows on the other side.  Suddenly, he stops. NEW ANGLE - SHOOTING PAST MacIlwain to an open window on the second floor in the house opposite.  The lace curtains move in the gentle morning breeze and beyond them can be seen the flashing oval mirror held between two horns of wood above an ornate dresser.  The room is a bedroom and so far as can be seen, it is empty. CLOSE FULL SHOT of MacIlwain as he takes a few more steps down the street and pauses to look again. ANOTHER ANGLE - This is the same setup as the previous one, SHOOTING PAST MacIlwain to SHOW the next window; a double one.  Through this window can be seen a stained oak sideboard and other evidences that this is a dining room.  At the table there can be clearly see through the window and on old white-haired woman.  She uses her napkin daintily against her lips and looks up.  Out of the gloom back of her comes a tall, thin blond young man dressed in a neat business suit and carrying a tan hat in his hand.  He leans forward and kisses the old woman.  After he straightens from the kiss, she pats his arm affectionately and they speak together for a few seconds but their words cannot be heard because of the great distance.  Then he bends to peck at her cheek again, turns and disappears into the darkness at the other end of the room. FULL SHOT - MacIlwain.  He takes his glance from the window, rummages through his pocket for a cigarette, then for matches, all the while watching the door of the house opposite.  Just as that door opens, he strikes the match and brings his cupped hands, shielding the flame, before his face. LONG SHOT - The doorway from MacIlwain's angle.  The young man comes out, goes down the steps and starts off toward Broadway. CLOSE SHOT - MacIlwain watching him over the flame of his match.  He lights his cigarette, blows out the match and throws it away, still standing watching him.

dialogues.speaker: MORNING
dialogues.text: CLOSE FULL SHOT of the window.  A white-capped chef is busily baking hot cakes, tossing them with histrionic skill.  So used are the passersby to this sight of culinary legerdemain that no one pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. LONG SHOT - The patrons absorbed in their newspapers and their breakfasts.  Sally Notcheck in waitress uniform passes the CAMERA.  The CAMERA DOLLIES with her as, tray in hand, she walks hastily toward the kitchen.  With an expert flip of her left arm she opens the swinging door and bobs through with her tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Sally Notcheck comes through the door, two waitresses and the manager stand within a foot or two of the door waiting for her.  One of the waitresses, Blanche, is a woman about fifty, heavily rouged and madeup.  The makeup on this harsh, lined face assumes a grotesque effect.  Her arms and hands show the muscles of a veteran waitress.  The other girl, Sylvia, young, frivolous is about Sally's age, but much wiser in the ways of the world she knows.  The manager, white coated, his trousers sharply creased, his hair pomaded to the shine of a skating rink, is the first to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sally, you can't keep us in suspense -- then what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But a customer was looking for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I ran down stairs and yelled for Mrs. Mainwairing.  She called the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was he her steady boyfriend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess so.  Mrs. Mainwairing said so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had you seen him before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sally takes a look through the little square window in the door toward her table. LONG SHOT - Through the little window from Sally's ANGLE showing a rather nice-looking man in a neat business suit as he comes in and seats himself at Sally's table.  He reaches for the menu. GROUP SHOT - Sally and the others as Sally looks nervously over her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to get back.  Another customer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She picks up an empty tray and starts back toward the dining room.  As she goes through the door, the manager turns to Sylvia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next time you go.  I want to hear what happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a quiet biddy, that Sally.  I never heard her speak so much in my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never get nothin' out of her.  Murder happens right in front of her nose and you get about five words on it -- between customers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE FULL SHOT - As Sally comes up to the new customer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young man looks up pleasantly.  He is Bob Shulman, a clerk in the employ of The Arden Rubber Novelties Corporation.  He is about twenty-four, city born and bred, but without the ingrown pugnaciousness of most New Yorkers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The usual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. CLOSE SHOT - Sally.  She is embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The usual? Oh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Obviously she doesn't remember what it is that this regular customer wants for his breakfast. TWO SHOT - Shulman notices this and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean the usual thing for breakfast -- hot cakes and coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sally smiles at him, deftly pours out water into his glass, then turns and goes off toward the front of the restaurant where the hot-cake orders are given to the chef in the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blanche, Sylvia and the manager peer through the little window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's gone off to order hot cakes.  We'll never hear about that murder.

dialogues.speaker: MORNING
dialogues.text: This is the hallway in which the employees of the company pass on their way to work.  A rack on the wall holds their cards and a battery of time clocks waits to greet them in the morning and speed their departure at night.  At this moment these time clocks are clacking away quite merrily as the employees queue up to punch in. The young man whom MacIlwain had watching leaving his house enters the hallway.  Without a word he goes to the rack and picks out a card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The card is made out to keep a record of the time of Harold Briggs, Clerk, Recieving Dept. MED. FULL SHOT - With his card in his hand Briggs crosses and takes his place in a queue in front of one of the time clocks.  In front of him are two girls.  They are chattering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friday is always such a busy day for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot of work come in on Friday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no.  I have to get my hair done and mother wants me to buy fish on my way home.  Friday is such a long day; the day before date night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She clangs down the handle of the time clock, takes her card and moves on.  Briggs punches in.  As he depresses the handle a heavy hand descends on his shoulders.  He moves nervously.  Behind him is a grinning acquaintance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi-yah, chum?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Moving away) Can't complain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks across the room to the door leading to the main office.

dialogues.speaker: MORNING
dialogues.text: This is an enormous room at one side of which is a long series of big windows with ventilator transoms top and bottom.  The various departments are separated from each other by railings, counters and partitions of milled glass.  In the LONG SHOT it looks like some intricate and modernistic maze for the confusion of office boys. Briggs comes in through the main door and threads his way through the various desks, counters and partitions to the square of desks and filing cabinets marked "Receiving."  He goes to one of the desks, seats himself, pulls open a drawer and takes out two files which he places before him. Then he looks over nervously at the neighboring desk, the top of which is still clear. He leafs through the files before him, almost without comprehension of what he is doing, then takes another look at the desk next to him and back again at the way he had come. The man he is seeking is evidently not in sight. But from his left, a tall, thin, older man, Mr. Johnson, approaches his desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Briggs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Mr. Johnson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In a kindly manner) Go on, Briggs, get your smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fellows with nicotine on your thumbs are never worth anything to the company until you've had your morning dra

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm waiting for Shulman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (As he moves on) Don't wait too long. We've got a lot of work to get out this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Briggs resumes his idle fingering of the two files before him, then suddenly the sound of footsteps behind him make him turn. The pleasant young man who had been breakfastin the restaurant comes into the Receiving Department a smil greeting on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Ralph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Briggs gets up from his chair. As he turns, and Shulman s his face for the first time; Shulman stops smiling and lo concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter, Ralph?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Briggs comes closer to him before answering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In a low flat voice) I killed her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shulman looks at him with shook and disbelief.  There is pause before he can find words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you ГўВЂВ” I killed her ГўВЂВ” I killed Dorothy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shulman continued to look at him for a moment then beckon him turns and starts out of the Receiving cubicle.  Brigg follows him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a row of sinks flanked by partitioned stalls. Th urinals are out of CAMERA, range. A man bent over one of wash basins, his coat off, his sleeves rolled, is splashi his face with water. He finishes these sketchy ablutions, pulls out an enormous number of paper towels and swabs himself dry. As this man begins to put on his tie. Shulma and Briggs enter. They search their pockets for cigarette and matches, light up and wait for the other man to put o his jacket and depart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see ГўВЂВ”-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shulman interrupts with an upraised finger, then bends down and looks under the door of the toilet compartment. Evidently his scrutiny has revealed no telltale feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why? What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't stand it any more ГўВЂВ” all that beefing and fighting.  I hit her. She began to bawl and I wanted to stop that awful bawling and whining.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is the sound of the door opening; the low hiss of compressed air in the door-closing device. Shulman makes gesture for silence. A moment later a dapper young man co in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi-yah, fellas! Wonderful morning. (He sniffs ecstatically) Air like wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both Shulman and Briggs nod, to him. He struts past them the mirror and begins to carefully adjust the Windsor kno his tie, all the while humming, "What a Wonderful Morning Having fixed the tie to the precise triangular exactitude his desire, he turns and struts out.  Immediately Briggs resumes his confession.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had to do it ГўВЂВ” kind of funny, way she made me do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I know you've been having trouble.  But what are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody see you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you leave anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody in the house know you were calling on her ГўВЂВ” the landlady?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorothy didn't like her; didn't talk to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then nobody saw you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you're in the clear.  Just don't talk about it ГўВЂВ”do anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you see ГўВЂВ”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are interrupted for a second time by the whooshing s of the door closing. A lean, little man in an alpaca coat comes in, goes past to the wash basin, removes a bottle of mouthwash from his pocket, uncorks it, takes a brief swallow and runs it bac and forth in his mouth, by briskly shaking his head, then spews it forth. He leaves, returning the cork to the bott

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were you saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her husband ГўВЂВ” he knows about me. They'll ask him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does he know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She told him everything. She used to needle him that way. Just like she did with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll be the first person the police will question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah ГўВЂВ” I've got to get out of here. But I need money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's your pay? You only got paid off day before yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gave it to Ma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Reaching Into his pocket for his wallet) I can skip my rent ГўВЂВ” I've always been up on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He counts out all but a few bills from the wallet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'll I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, take the money anyhow. Got any friends outside the city?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Briggs shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you go on vacation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know ГўВЂВ” Ma and I go to Ceagirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People know you there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah ГўВЂВ” It's a little place. We've been going there for years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's no good then. Go to Stamford -- go to the "Y" there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what about Ma?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shulman tries to think this out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't she know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll call herГўВЂВ” tell her you had to go out of town for the company and I'll tell Mr. Johnson that you're been taken sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't call Ma.  That upsets her. Go see her, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door warns them again.  Two men come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you she's a dream boat adrift on the river of love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Ecstatically) A dream boat ГўВЂВ”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shulman gestures toward the door and he and Briggs start As they go Briggs speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll go and fix things with my Ma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shulman nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blinds have been pulled down to the window sills but brightness of noon light steals in through every crevice that the room is in a dim light. MaoIlwain lies on the be sleeping soundly with only a sheet pulled over his pajama clad body. A black eye bandage is over his eyes and rubbe stopples in his ears. From outside comes the yammering an shouting of innumerable children at play in the street wi an obligato of taxi horns and the roar of traffic on a ne avenue. There is a knock at the door. MacIlwain does not stir. Th knock is repeated louder. Still there is no response. The even more thunderous hammering of knuckles on the door pa This finally rouses the sleeper. He shucks the eye shade, removes the stopples, glances at the alarm clock beside h bed, curses under his breath and finally lowers his feet the floor and staggers across the room and opens the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Through the door) Mr. MacIlwain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitchell comes through the door. He is dressed in civilian clothes.  He shows his badge in the palm of his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Mitchell ГўВЂВ” police department.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (What do you want?)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to speak to you about Mrs.  MacIlwain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your pals have been here.  I told 'em ГўВЂВ” we're divorced.  I don't know anything about her. I don't know any of her friends. What do you want to know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Stumped) Well, you see, I thought you might give me a lead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you I don't know anything. I paid my alimony and I stayed away from her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But didn't you ever hear of any friends she had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went into all that with your friends from homicide.  If she had any friends I didn't know about 'em. How let me get some sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mitchell allows himself to be forced out of the room. MacIlwain closes the door, then turns back into his room sits down on the edge of the bed. He looks at the alarm clock; the hands point to ten minutes after twelve. He be to put back the stopples In his ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lunch-hour rush is on. It is a hot day and half the m in the restaurant are in their shirt sleeves. The place steams with heat, activity and food. MED. FULL SHOT -Sally as she arranges Jacks' setup and po his water. The handsome salesman is studying a newspaper, holding it before him at a distance that would indicate either eye defect or the assumption of a high-bred manner Sally's hands fluttering about him neither distract nor interest him. Suddenly she points with her forefinger to headline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Hesitantly) I saw the man who did it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Jacks looks at her. Probably it is the first time he looked at her.  He even speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sally is almost overcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I did. I saw him. I live in that house ГўВЂВ” on the same floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This little interchange of words has drawn his attention to her. He looks her over paying particular regard to that portion of her anatomy where the cotton cloth of her uniform in strained tightly over her bosoms. He seems to approve what he sees.  It is at this moment, however, that Shulman pushes his way past Sally and takes the single seat opposite Jacks. He picks up his menu and looks it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (To Sally) You're a cute trick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sally is flustered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, ГўВЂВ” I might have news for you kid ГўВЂВ” good news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might even make bright the evening for you, dearie. Where do you live?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah -- makes It convenient doesn't it? What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sally Notoheck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Funny name, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess so. A lot of people have said so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well ГўВЂВ” a rose by any other name, you know.    What're you doing tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friday night and you ain't doin' nothing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.
